newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: COMMONWEALTH TAX OFFICIALS MEET IN HARARE.
newsitem.headline: COMMONWEALTH TAX OFFICIALS MEET IN HARARE.

text.p: Tax administrators from 45 Commonwealth countries began a meeting in Harare on Monday to discuss ways of harnessing modern technology to improve the efficiency of tax collection in their countries.

Conference chairman, Gerry Cook of the United Kingdom's Inland Revenue said most tax administrations in the world were computerising and Commonwealth countries -- many of whom suffered shortages of qualified and skilled staff -- were also looking at automation to improve tax collection systems.
"Technology is a big issue of discussion at the conference and most of the tax administrations in the Commonwealth are introducing computers, automation to improve collections.
"Using computers ensures a very quick turnaround of tax assessments and means big savings in the cost of running the tax administration," Cook told Reuters.

In a speech read at the opening of the three-day conference, Zimbabwean Finance Minister Herbert Murerwa said most Commonwealth countries were failing to take full advantage of available technology to improve their tax administrations.

"In a world that is fast becoming a global village, it is the strength and capacity of tax administration that can make or break the desired economic and social being of a nation," Murerwa said in the speech read by his deputy, Patrick Chinamasa.

"It is therefore important for tax administrators to be kept abreast of the developments in business practices and technological advancement, lest they fall prey to gullible and smart tax evaders," he said.

He said Zimbabwe was taking steps to make its tax administration more efficient and effective. He said it was restructuring its tax administration departments to bring them under a semi-autonomous revenue authority.
"With the liberalisation of our economy, strengthening of the tax administration capacity has and remains high on our agenda," he said.
